_exec_summary.SummaryText:
GENERAL CHEMICAL CORP. 
DELAWARE VALLEY WORKS
RMP REGISTRATION

Submission Type:
[  ]   First Time RMP Submission
[ ]   Correction  to Current RMP
[(]   Re-Submission

Executive Summary

This amended Risk Management Plan (RMP) is submitted by General Chemical Corporation¿s Delaware Valley Works in compliance with the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68 for management of Methyl Chloride, Anhydrous Ammonia, Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride, and Oleum.  At General Chemical Delaware Valley Works, four listed chemicals are managed on-site in quantities greater than the threshold quantity under the USEPA¿s program level 3 criteria.  No chemicals are managed on-site under program 1 or program 2 criteria. The chemicals managed according to USEPA¿s program level 3 criteria include Anhydrous Ammonia, Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride, Oleum, and Methyl Chloride.  Methyl Chloride is a component found in some forms of the spent acid received for regeneration at Delaware Valley Works.  Although General Chemical Delaware Valley Works is not currently receiving spent acid containing this component, General Chemical is filing a predictive RMP for future use of Methyl Chloride.  As identified in this plan, Delaware Valley Works is in compliance with the requirements of USEPA¿s 40 CFR Part 68 for management of Methyl Chloride, Anhydrous Ammonia, Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride, and Oleum.

This amended RMP describes Delaware Valley Work¿s risk management program, which includes a hazard assessment, release prevention program and emergency response program. The hazard assessment includes one worst-case release scenario and four alternative case release scenarios. The hazard assessment was conducted in accordance with 40 CFR Part 68, Subpart B (68.20-68.42), as well as the USEPA¿s Off-site Consequence Analysis Guidance Document. The release prevention and emergency response programs at Delaware Valley Works were developed based on requirements of the CAA¿s Accidental Release Prevention Pro

visions, the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard, the American Chemistry Council¿s (ACC) Responsible Care Initiatives, and the Delaware Extremely Hazardous Substances Regulation.  All information identified in the attached registration form is current as of December 31, 2002.

This RMP was prepared in accordance with 40 CFR Part 68, Subpart G (68.150-68.190), which provides a format for a written RMP and submitted using the RMP Submit¿ electronic format.  The required elements of an RMP, as defined by the USEPA, are listed below along with the section in which they are located in this RMP.  All information identified in the attached registration form is current as of December 31, 2002.

* Section 1.0 ¿ Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
* Section 2.0 ¿ Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 
* Section 3.0 ¿ Hazard Assessment
* Section 4.0 ¿ General Accidental Release Prevention Programs and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
* Section 5.0 ¿ Five Year Accident History
* Section 6.0 ¿ Emergency Response Program 
* Section 7.0 ¿ Planned Changes to Improve Safety

  
1.0	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

General Chemical Corporation recognizes that the responsible management of health, safety and the environment in and around its facilities is one of its highest corporate priorities and a key element in its successful business strategy. General Chemical Corporation is committed to implementing policies and procedures, which ensure that its operations are conducted in compliance with applicable laws and regulations.  Achieving responsible health, safety and environmental management will be accomplished by: operating our facilities safely and prudently; efficiently using energy and materials; seeking ways to minimize or reuse wastes; and otherwise complying fully with all applicable local, state, and federal laws and regulations.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to

prevent and/or mitigate foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, Delaware Valley Works has prepared employees, in conjunction with local emergency response groups, to respond to a release. 

2.0	Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 

General Chemical¿s DVW site is a complex operation that manufactures specialty and industrial chemicals.  These products include sulfur-based chemicals, fluoborates, sulfuric acid, and other specialty products.  Delaware Valley Works occupies 130 acres on the lower Delaware River.  It is divided into North and South portions by Philadelphia Pike.  The North Plant, located in Pennsylvania, contains batch reactors used to make specialty chemicals products.  The South Plant, located in Delaware, houses the sulfuric acid plant and units for making photo salt products.  Supports facilities at the plant include warehouse space, product-packaging line, loading and unloading facilities for trucks, and railcars.  The plant also contains it own product testing laboratory, as well as research and development facilities.

General Chemical Delaware Valley Works has four  (4) listed chemicals that are managed on site in quantities greater than the threshold quantity under the program level 3 criteria.  No chemicals are managed on-site under program 1 or program 2 criteria.  The chemicals managed according to program level 3 criteria include Anhydrous Ammonia (CAS Number: 007664-41-7), Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride (CAS Number: 007664-39-3), Oleum (CAS Number: 008014-95-7), and Methyl Chloride (CAS Number: 0074-87-3).  Methyl Chloride is a component found in some forms of the spent acid received for regenerated at Delaware Valley Works.  Although General Chemical Delaware Valley Works is not currently receiving spent acid containing this component, General Chemical is filing a predictive RMP for future use of Methyl Chloride.  As identified in this plan, Delaware Valley Works is in compl

iance with requirements of 40 CFR Part 68 for management of Anhydrous Ammonia, Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride, Oleum and Methyl Chloride.

The seven (7) processes at Delaware Valley Works use one or more of the regulated chemicals identified above.  The processes and associated regulated chemical(s) are outlined below:

3.0	Hazard Assessment

USEPA¿s Accidental Release Prevention Provisions require that General Chemical provide information about the worst case release scenario and the four alternative case release scenarios for Anhydrous Ammonia, Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride, Oleum and Methyl Chloride handled at its Delaware Valley Works.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios.

3.1	Worst Case Release Scenario

The worst-case release scenario as defined by the USEPA is a hypothetical accident for one of the chemicals at a site.  It assumes that all safety systems in the facility simultaneously fai

l and that entire quantity of chemical in the largest container holding it at a site is released in a very short time. A USEPA-RMP Comp¿ modeling software defines the distance the material will travel until it disperses so much that it is no longer hazardous.  

The worst case release scenario at General Chemical¿s Delaware Valley Works assumes that a storage tank containing Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride for the Potassium Fluoride/ Bifluoride process located at the North Plant structurally fails. The USEPA requires us to assume that all safety and release prevention systems fail, and the contents are released in 10 minutes.  The USEPA- RMP Comp¿ release scenario modeling software, states that the material released would travel 15 miles before it reaches a non-hazardous concentration. 

3.2	Alternative Case Release Scenarios

The alternative case scenario is a more credible hypothetical, site-specific or company specific chemical release. It takes into account safety and release prevention systems and procedures used at the facility to control releases. It is more realistic than the worst case scenario; is also calculated using the USEPA- RMP Comp¿ modeling software; and, is used to plan a facility¿s emergency response to accidents. 

3.2.1	The alternative case release scenario for Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride at Delaware Valley Works assumes Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride would be lost due to the failure of an unloading hose during the transfer process. The USEPA- RMP Comp¿ modeling software states that the material released would travel 0.2 miles before reaching a non-hazardous concentration. 

3.2.2 The alternative case release scenario for Oleum at Delaware Valley Works assumes Oleum would be lost due to failure of a loading line during the transfer process. The USEPA- RMP Comp¿ modeling software states that the material released would travel 0.2 miles before reaching a non-hazardous concentration
 

3.2.3 The alternative case release scenario for Methyl C

hloride at Delaware Valley Works assumes Methyl Chloride would be lost due to failure of a Spent Acid unloading hose during the transfer process. The USEPA- RMP Comp¿ modeling software states that the material released would travel 0.10 miles before reaching a non-hazardous concentration

3.2.4 The alternative case release scenario for Anhydrous Ammonia at Delaware Valley Works assumes Anhydrous Ammonia would be lost due to the failure of an unloading hose during the transfer process.  The USEPA- RMP Comp¿ modeling software states that the material released would travel 0.2 miles before reaching a non-hazardous concentration.
4.0 General Accidental Release Prevention Programs and Chemical ¿ Specific Prevention Steps 

General Chemical maintains a comprehensive release prevention program designed to prevent accidental releases and ensure safe operations of our processes.  The accidental release prevention program implemented at Delaware Valley Works includes procedures and practices which address each of the required elements of the risk management program including:

* Process Safety Information ¿ Information relating to the hazards of the chemical(s), process technology and equipment information is maintained to ensure proper operation.

* Mechanical Integrity ¿ Maintenance of mechanical equipment is of prime importance to the overall operating performance of a facility.  Equipment must be in proper operating condition for the system to maintain peak performance.  A sudden and unexpected breakdown of equipment can cause problems throughout the facility.  These types of problems can be minimized when a proper maintenance program is set up and followed.

With this in mind, Delaware Valley Works has developed its maintenance program.  Inspections and services are based on the recommendations of experienced engineers and operators, the maintenance guides of equipment manufacturers, and industry standards.  The following is an excerpt from sections of the Ins

pection, Testing and Preventative Maintenance Manual (ITPM).

The Delaware Valley Works personnel perform three types of routine maintenance to ensure the operability and mechanical integrity of critical equipment handling extremely hazardous substances (EHSs), as well as additional equipment deemed appropriate by facility personnel:

	1. Pressure Vessels and Storage Tanks
	2. Piping and Piping Components
	3. Relief, vent systems and devices
	4. Emergency shutdown systems
	5. Controls and interlocks
	6. Pumps

A list of the critical equipment in EHS service and the applicable type of routine maintenance is maintained as an integral part of the program.  Details on the procedures for each type of routine maintenance are described in ITPM Manual.  Documentation of the test and inspection results is also discussed. 

If equipment does not meet accepted criteria of the inspection or test, the owning department will be notified by the Reliability Engineer or the Electrician/Instrumentation Technician.  It is the owning department's responsibility to initiate a work order of fixed capital request to make repairs. If the equipment is determined unsafe, it must be taken out of service until repairs are made.

All ITPM actions concerning instrumentation will be handled by the I/E Department and will not be the responsibility of the Reliability Department.  In conjunction with ISO 9000 procedures, instrumentation covered by PSM will be tracked using specialized software.  A comprehensive table of PSM covered instrumentation lists all the pertinent data concerning each piece of instrumentation.  Calibrations are scheduled monthly and are also conducted during process shutdowns.  Accompanying each schedule is a plant standard / checklist for proper execution of calibrations, tests and inspections.  These procedures come directly from the manufacturer¿s catalogs.  A complete file of manufacturers¿ catalogs is located in the I/E Department.  All I/E personnel are t

rained by the senior I/E engineer on all instrumentation and ITPM procedures, to include Quality Assurance procedures.

Certain PSM covered kinematic equipment, including agitators and pumps, will be vibration tested quarterly as per industry standard.  Vibration routes have been developed by the Reliability Department for each PSM covered process identifying specific testing points for each piece of equipment.  A detailed history of vibration measurement is maintained in conjunction with the vibration test software. Historical trends for each piece of equipment are created and used to predict possible failure of kinematic equipment.   A complete listing of each route is available in the Reliability department.

* Process Hazard Analysis ¿ Processes are routinely analyzed to identify and correct potential hazards, as well as, increase the safety of the operating conditions.

* Standard Operating Procedures ¿ Detailed procedures are in place identifying actions necessary for multiple phases of operation, operating limits and safety considerations. The procedures provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involving covered processes consistent with the Process Safety Information.  They also include steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations and safety systems and their functions.  The procedures are readily accessible to our employees who work on or maintain a covered process.  The process foreperson, or his/ her designee, in conjunction with the affected employees, review the procedures as often as necessary, but at a minimum annually, to assure they reflect current operating practice.  In addition, Delaware Valley Works Environmental, Health and Safety Policies and Procedures Manual documents the safe work practices such as hot work, lockout/tagout and confined space entry.

* Employee Participation ¿ Employees at all levels are involved in key roles of the release prevention program.  

* Training ¿

Employees operating a Delaware Valley Works covered process are trained in the overview of the process and in the operating procedures addressed previously. This training emphasizes specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations and safe work practices. Initial training occurs before initial assignment to work independently and they have demonstrated the required knowledge, skills and abilities. Documented refresher training is required at least every three years.

* Management of Change ¿ Process parameters are maintained through a management of change system which documents the changes, as well as, evaluates the changes for safety.  Delaware Valley Works Management of Change procedure is designed to ensure the safety of plant personnel and the process operations is not compromised by inadequate evaluation of changes.  The formal review and approval of all process and equipment changes prior to their implementation is required by this procedure.  Delaware Valley Works has chosen to incorporate the Management of Change procedure to all changes not just those involving covered processes.

* Pre-startup Safety Review ¿ Significant changes to the processes are evaluated in detail in order to verify that the proper procedures for engineering, operations, emergency response and overall safety are addressed prior to start-up.

* Incident Investigation ¿ All incidents are investigated to ensure proper modifications are made to reduce or eliminate the potential for re-occurrence.

* Safe Works Practices ¿ Standard safety practices are in place to help insure worker safety including lockout/tagout procedures, control of entry into process areas, line breaking procedures, confined space entry procedures and hot work procedures.

* Contractor Safety ¿ Contractors are evaluated and trained prior to performing work on-site to reduce the potential of an incident. 

* Compliance Audits ¿ Audits are performed at a minimum of three-year intervals to verify pro

cedures and practices are adequate and are being followed.

* Emergency Response ¿ Plans are made with the community emergency response groups as well as on-site emergency response teams to ensure procedures are in place in case an emergency situation occurs.
In addition to this general accidental release prevention program, General Chemical¿s Delaware Valley Works has taken additional chemical-specific prevention steps designed to perform the following: 

* quickly detect a release of an extremely hazardous substance; 
* contain or control a release of an extremely hazardous substance;
* and/or, reduce the consequences of a release of an extremely hazardous substance.

The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

Early Detection

* Process temperature and pressure controls

* Operator surveillance of all process areas

* Camera monitored surveillance 

* Area monitoring for early detection systems

Release Containment and Control

* Pressure relief devices on pressurized storage units and process vessels

* Secondary containment for storage units

* Check valves on unloading systems

* Automatic and manual shutdown systems on process equipment
Release Mitigation
* Emergency shutdown procedures

* Deluge systems

Consequence Reduction

* Trained emergency response personnel 

* Notification procedures for plant personnel and local officials

* Personal protective equipment for emergency response personnel

* Emergency Response plans prepared with local emergency response officials 

5.0	The Five Year Accident History

During the five years immediately prior to the date of this report, the following accidental releases were experienced at the General Chemical Corp. Delaware Valley Works Facility.  The five-year accident history allows Delaware Valley Works personnel to explain to the community the factors causing or contributing to accidental releases, the on-site and off-site impacts of acciden

tal releases, and the procedural and technological changes made to minimize the likelihood that these accidental releases will occur again.  The intent of this information exchange is to create an informed community while also documenting that accidental releases are investigated and concrete changes are made to protect against reoccurrence.

Delaware Valley Works personnel reviewed all incident investigation reports from January 1998 to present to identify accidental releases of four regulated, program 3 hazardous chemicals.  The accidental releases included in the history were those that resulted in released quantities greater than the listed federal release quantity (RQ) for the hazardous chemical or resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or known off site deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage. Data regarding these incidents 
are described below:

6.0      Emergency Response Program

General Chemical¿s Delaware Valley Works maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our plan with the Delaware County (PA) and New Castle County (DE) Local Emergency Planning Commissions (LEPCs).  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committees, which are comprised of local government

officials, local emergency response officials, and industry representatives.  Delaware Valley Works, the LEPCs and the local fire departments have coordinated communication to notify the public quickly, if necessary, as well as facilitate quick response to an incident. In addition to periodic committee meetings, Delaware Valley Works conducts periodic emergency response drills that involve emergency response organizations.    

7.0 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Delaware Valley Works performs periodic process hazard analysis to evaluate and to strive continuously to improve health, safety and environmental performance as technical developments, scientific understanding, consumer and community needs, and regulatory requirements evolve and change, some of which result in process modifications.  For example, the following improvements are currently planned for Delaware Valley Works:

* Addition of process controls (pressure switches and sensors, temperature alarms and switches, flow control valves etc.) as an increased means for maintaining safe operating parameters during normal operations and railcar loading/ unloading in the Fluosulfonic Acid process.
* Providing additional warning lights and signals as safety precautions to prevent personnel from entering highly hazardous chemical areas when sensitive operations are occurring in the Fluosulfonic Railcar Loading/ Unloading area.
* Modification of the Fluosulfonic Acid Process Scrubber to increase the scrubbing and flow capacity to prevent the release of Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride, Sulfur Dioxide, and Fluosulfonic Acid vapors to the atmosphere.
* The addition of an access platform to the top of the Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride storage tank to provide safer access to all process control systems.
